Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: A Heterogeneous Testbed for Exploring Emerging HPC Tools, Programming Languages, and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Parallel computing is in the midst of exciting changes. Virtually all new processors have multiple cores exposing all applications to parallelism. GPUs are processors of choice for many compute intensive applications, making heterogeneity another reality of the HPC landscape. These characteristics pose tough challenges to application developers as well as system level software architects. This project plans to develop the infrastructure to support research into programming models, tools and runtime systems for emerging HPC systems.
The project creates a heterogeneous compute cluster with core aspects of emerging high-end systems. The system will have a high degree of parallelism distributed on a modest number of nodes by maximizing the cores per node up to 32. It utilizes multiple heterogeneous CPU architectures and deploy compute accelerators. The storage system is based on solid-state disks (SSDs), an emerging technology that allows two orders of magnitude lower latencies than magnetic hard drives.
The research conducted on this system focuses on various aspects of the execution tool chain. Specific research projects supported include: OpenMP compiler and run-time system for multi-core architectures and accelerators; automatic optimization of compute and communication operations in heterogeneous environments; highly fault-tolerant execution in heterogeneous and volunteer environments; and optimization of parallel I/O operations for low latency storage devices. Furthermore, collaborative work with applications scientists is expected to lead to the development of advanced parallelization strategies for various application domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to purchase, deploy and operate a heterogeneous compute cluster for high performance computing systems related researchers at the University of Houston. The compute system purchased over duration of multiple years consists of compute nodes using cutting edge Intel, AMD, NVIDIA and ARM processors; a storage system based on of Solid State Drives; and a power measurement unit.

The system was purchased and installed gradually over the years, with the first and largest part being operational since early summer 2011. The hardware purchased as part of this project was an invaluable resource for the development of highly popular tools in the high performance computing community, including the Open MPI and OpenSHMEM communication libraries, the OpenUH compiler, and the BOINC and VOLPEX distributed execution environment. Thus, the project benefited researchers in the entire United States.

This grant has provided hardware support for numerous research project funded both by NSF as well as other funding agencies such as DOE and DOD. The AMD nodes of the cluster allowed researchers to gain experience with large number of compute cores per node, by having nodes with core-counts which exceeded what was typically available in 2011, but is common nowadays. Tt gave researchers at the University of Houston a head-start on the challenges occurring on such systems. The heterogeneous nature of the cluster allowed to explore programming models for compute accelerators, each of which has specific merits and drawbacks. The heterogeneity was also critical for the usage of the cluster for Volpex, a system specifically designed to manage execution on heterogeneous resources. The Intel nodes of the cluster along with the power measurement units contributed towards the development of new methods for power centric code development and optimizations. The Solid State Storage gave researchers the opportunity to develop optimizations for this technology before it was widely available.

The different kinds of architectural parallelism offered by the procured platform have made it also an invaluable resource for teaching and student training activities. The compute resources purchased through this project have been used in numerous courses, including graduate courses on Computer Architecture, Parallel Computation, Shared Memory Programming, Programming Languages, and Compilers. Students contributed towards the assembly, installation and maintenance of the cluster. This hands-on experience is highly valued in industry, since it exposes students to problems and aspects of system level work that can typically not be covered in class-room settings.
